nodes.body:
```
Error: ./././Mathlib/Algebra/CharP/ExpChar.lean:72:1: error: ringExpChar.eq_one.{u_1} simp can prove this:
  by simp only [@ringChar.eq_zero, @ge_iff_le, @zero_le, @max_eq_right]
```

Oops. I assume that `abbrev ringExpChar` allows `simp` to expand the definition of it? So I should remove the `simp` tag from `ringExpChar.eq_one`? Or change `abbrev` to `def`?

> Oops. I assume that `abbrev ringExpChar` allows `simp` to expand the definition of it? So I should remove the `simp` tag from `ringExpChar.eq_one`? Or change `abbrev` to `def`?

I'd be fine with changing it to a def. I noticed sometimes you can't `rw` or `simp_rw` the definition of an abbrev, which can be annoying.

bors d+

`ExpChar.exists` etc. all uses domain, so let's use it here too:
```suggestion
theorem exists' (R : Type*) [NonAssocRing R] [IsDomain R] :
```
No, it doesn't work as `IsDomain R` requires `R` to be an associated ring.

This is the purpose of introducing `exists'` :)
```suggestion
  obtain _ | âŸ¨p, âŸ¨hpâŸ©, _âŸ© := CharP.exists' R
  exacts [âŸ¨1, .zeroâŸ©, âŸ¨p, .prime hpâŸ©]
```
On the other hand `R` should be explicit here, since `hq` is provided as an instance.
Is `R` explicit here? I think it should be.
You mean "should not", right?
Yes, sorry.

```suggestion
theorem ringExpChar.eq_one (R : Type*) [NonAssocSemiring R] [CharZero R] : ringExpChar R = 1 := by
```
